message_1:
Consider the following propositional logic statements:
P: It is sunny today.
Q: I will go for a walk.

Assume that the truth value of statement P is true and the truth value of statement Q is false. What would be the truth value of the following proposition: "If it is sunny today, then I will go for a walk"?
message_2: The given proposition can be represented as an implication: P â†’ Q. The truth value of an implication is false only when the antecedent (P) is true and the consequent (Q) is false. In this case, P is true and Q is false, so the truth value of the proposition "If it is sunny today, then I will go for a walk" is false.
